title: The Translational Digestive Disease Research Center (TDDR) at the University of Michigan
text: The Translational DIgestive Disease Research (TDDR) Center at the University of Michigan is a DIgestive Disease Research Core Center funded by the National Institutes of Health via a P30 grant from the National Institute Of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney (NIDDK) diseases. This Center administers 3 cores and 2 programs to enhance the productivity of researchers in gastrointestinal and hepatic diseases.

title: The Translational Digestive Disease Research Center (TDDR) at the University of Michigan
text:
The Programs
The TDDR Center includes two programs:

The Enrichment Program
This program is responsible for several activities that enrich the scientific environment for digestive disease research at the University of Michigan, including the fortnightly in-person gatherings on Wednesday afternoons, Bring Back a Technique (BBAT) mini-sabbaticals, Collaboration Seed Grants (CSG), and our annual Research Retreat.
The Pilot & Feasibility Program
This program is responsible for advertising, soliticing, and evaluating applications for pilot and feasibility grants of up to $50,000 to fund research leading to preliminary data toward a larger NIH-funded grant.
